note.p: The title page is engraved and signed "Guliel[mus] Hole fecit". The second state of the imprint (see The Library, ser. 6, 8:152-6).

The subsidiary plays each have separate dated title pages. Of these, "Every man out of his humour", "Cynthia's revels", and "Poetaster" have title pages in varying states; see Greg for details. Pagination and register are continuous.
A number of sheets exist in two different settings, and certain of these appear to be reprints done much later; see Greg and "Studies in Bibliography" 40:106-20.
A second volume was published without general title page in 1631.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: POËTASTER, OR His Arraignement. A Comicall Satyre. Acted, in the yeere 1601. By the then Children of Queene ELIZABETHS CHAPPEL.

quote.l: Et mihi de nullo fama rubore placet.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by WILLIAM STANSBY, for Matthew Lownes.

div.head: TO THE VERTVOVS, AND MY WORTHY FRIEND, Mr. Richard Martin.
div.p: SIr, A thankefull man owes a courtesie euer: the vnthankefull, but when he needes it. To make mine owne marke appeare, and shew by which of these seales I am known, I send you this peece of what may liue of mine; for whose innocence, as for the Authors, you were once a noble and timely vndertaker, to the greatest Iustice of this kingdome. Enioy now the delight of your goodnesse; which is to see that prosper, you preseru'd: and posteritie to owe the reading of that, without offence, to your name; which so much ignorance, and malice of the times, then conspir'd to haue supprest.

sp.speaker: ENVIE.
sp.l: LIght, Arising in the midst of the stage. I salute thee, but with wounded nerues:
Wishing thy golden splendor, pitchy darknesse.
What's here? TH'ARRAIGNMENT? I: This, this is it,
That our sunke eyes haue wak't for, all this while:
Here will be subiect for my snakes, and me.
Cling to my necke, and wrists, my louing wormes,
And cast you round, in soft, and amorous foulds,
Till I doe bid, vncurle: Then, breake your knots,
Shoot out your selues at length, as your forc't stings
Would hide themselues within his malic't sides,
To whom I shall apply you. Stay! the shine
Of this assembly here offends my sight,
I'le darken that first, and out-face their grace.
Wonder not, if I stare: these fifteene weekes
(So long as since the plot was but an embrion)
Haue I, with burning lights, mixt vigilant thoughts,
In expectation of this hated play:
To which (at last) I am arriu'd as Prologue.
Nor would I, you should looke for other lookes,
Gesture, or complement from me, then what
Th'infected bulke of ENVIE can afford:
For I am risse here with a couetous hope,
To blast your pleasures, and destroy your sports,
With wrestings, comments, applications,
Spie-like suggestions, priuie whisperings,
And thousand such promooting sleights as these.
Marke, how I will begin: The Scene is, ha!
ROME? ROME? and ROME? Cracke ey-strings, and your balles
Drop into earth; let me be euer blind.
I am preuented; all my hopes are crost,
Checkt, and abated; fie, a freezing sweate
Flowes forth at all my pores, my entrailes burne:
What should I doe? ROME? ROME? O my vext soule,
How might I force this to the present state?
Are there no players here? no poet-apes,
That come with basiliskes eyes, whose forked tongues
Are steept in venome, as their hearts in gall?
Eyther of these would helpe me; they could wrest,
Peruert, and poyson all they heare, or see,
With senselesse glosses, and allusions.
Now if you be good deuils, flye me not.
You know what deare, and ample faculties
I haue indow'd you with: Ile lend you more.
Here, take my snakes among you, come, and eate,
And while the squeez'd juice flowes in your blacke jawes,
Helpe me to damne the Authour. Spit it foorth
Vpon his lines, and shew your rustie teeth
At euerie word, or accent: or else choose
Out of my longest vipers, to sticke downe
In your deep throats; and let the heads come forth
At your ranke mouthes; that he may see you arm'd
With triple malice, to hisse, sting, and teare
His worke, and him; to forge, and then declame,
Traduce, corrupt, apply, enforme, suggest:
O, these are gifts wherein your soules are blest.
What? doe you hide your selues? will none appeare?
None answere? what, doth this calme troupe affright you?
Nay, then I doe despaire: downe, sinke againe.
This trauaile is all lost with my dead hopes.
If in such bosomes, spight haue left to dwell,
Enuie is not on earth, nor scarse in hell.

div.head: The third sounding. PROLOGVE.
div.l: STay, Monster, ere thou sinke, thus on thy head
Set we our bolder foot; with which we tread
Thy malice into earth: So spight should die,
Despis'd and scorn'd by noble industrie.
If any muse why I salute the stage,
An armed Prologue; know, 't is a dangerous age:
Wherein, who writes, had need present his Scenes
Fortie sold proofe against the coniuring meanes
Of base detractors, and illiterate apes,
That fill vp roomes in faire and formall shapes.
'Gainst these, haue we put on this forc't defence:
Whereof the allegorie and hid sence
Is, that a well erected confidence
Can fright their pride, and laugh their folly hence.
Here now, put case our Authour should, once more,
Sweare that his play were good; he doth implore,
You would not argue him of arrogance:
How ere that common spawne of ignorance,
Our frie of writers, may beslime his fame,
And giue his action that adulterate name.
Such ful-blowne vanitie he more doth lothe,
Then base deiection: There's a meane 'twixt both.
Which with a constant firmenesse he pursues,
As one, that knowes the strength of his owne muse.
And this he hopes all free soules will allow,
Others, that take it with a rugged brow,
Their moods he rather pitties, then enuies:
His mind it is aboue their iniuries.

sp.l: THen, when this bodie falls in funerall fire,
My name shall liue, and my best part aspire.
It shall goe so.

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Young master, master OVID, doe you heare? gods a mee! away with your songs, and sonnets; and on with your gowne and cappe, quickly: here, here, your father will be a man of this roome presently. Come, nay, nay, nay, nay, be briefe. These verses too, a poyson on 'hem, I cannot abide 'hem, they make mee readie to cast, by the bankes of helicon. Nay looke, what a rascally vntoward thing this poetrie is; I could teare 'hem now.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Giue me, how neere's my father?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Hart a'man: get a law-booke in your hand, I will not answere you else. Why so: now there's some formalitie in you. By IOVE, and three or foure of the gods more, I am right of mine olde masters humour for that; this villanous poetrie will vndoe you, by the welkin.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: What, hast thou buskins on, LVSCVS, that thou swear'st so tragically, and high?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: No, but I haue bootes on, sir, and so ha's your father too by this time: for he call'd for 'hem, ere I came from the lodging.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Why? was he no readier?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: O no; and there was the madde skeldring captaine, with the veluet armes, readie to lay hold on him as hee comes downe: he that presses euerie man he meets, with an oath, to lend him money, and cries; (Thou must doo't, old boy, as thou art a man, a man of worship.)

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Who? PANTILIVS TVCCA?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: I, hee: and I met little master LVPVS, the Tribune, going thither too.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Nay, and he be vnder their arrest, I may (with safetie inough) reade ouer my elegie, before he come.

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Gods a mee! what'll you doe? why, young master, you are not castalian mad, lunatike, frantike, desperate? ha?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: What ailest thou, LVSCVS?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: God be with you, sir, I'le leaue you to your poeticall fancies, and furies. I'le not be guiltie, I.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Be not, good ignorance: I'm glad th'art gone:
For thus alone, our eare shall better judge
The hastie errours of our morning muse.
Ouid Lib 1. Amo. Ele. 15. ENuie, why twitst thou me, my time's spent ill?
And call'st my verse, fruits of an idle quill?
Or that (vnlike the line from whence I sprung)
Wars dustie honours I pursue not young?
Or that I studie not the tedious lawes;
And prostitute my voyce to euerie cause?
Thy scope is mortall; mine eternall fame:
Which through the world shall euer chaunt my name.
HOMER will liue, whil'st TENEDOS stands, and IDE,
Or, to the sea, sleet SIMOIS doth slide:
And so shall HESIOD too, while vines doe beare,
Or crooked sickles crop the ripened care.
CALLIMACHVS, though in inuention lowe,
Shall still be sung: since he in art doth flowe.
No losse shall come to SOPHOCLES proud vaine.
With sunne, and moone, ARATVS shall remaine.
Whil'st slaues be false, fathers hard, and bawdes be whorish,
Whil'st harlots flatter, shall MENANDER flourish.
ENNIVS, though rude, and ACCIVS high-reard straine,
A fresh applause in euerie age shall gaine.
Of VARRO'S name, what eare shall not be told?
Of IASONS ARGO? and the fleece of gold?
Then shall LVCRETIVS loftie numbers die,
When earth, and seas in fire and flames shall frie.
TYTIRVS, Tillage, AENEE shall be read,
Whil'st ROME of all the conquer'd world is head.
Till CVPIDS fires be out, and his bowe broken,
Thy verses (neate TIBVLLVS) shall be spoken.
Our GALLVS shall be knowne from east to west:
So shall LYCORIS, whom he now loues best.
The suffering plough-share, or the flint may weare:
But heauenly poesie no death can feare.
Kings shall giue place to it, and kingly showes,
The bankes ore which gold-bearing Tagus flowes.
Kneele hindes to trash: me let bright PHOEBVS swell,
With cups full flowing from the MVSES well.
Frost-fearing myrtle shall impale my head,
And of sad louers Ile be often read.
"Enuie, the liuing, not the dead, doth bite:
" For after death all men receiue their right.
Then, when this bodie fals in funerall fire,
My name shall liue, and my best part aspire.

div.head: Act I. Scene II.
div.stage: OVID Senior, OVID Iunior, LVSCVS, TVCCA, LVPVS, PYRGVS.

sp.p: YOur name shall liue indeed, sir; you say true: but how infamously, how scorn'd and contemn'd in the eyes and eares of the best and grauest Romanes, that you thinke not on: you neuer so much as dreame of that. Are these the fruits of all my trauaile and expenses? is this the scope and aime of thy studies? are these the hopefull courses, wherewith I haue so long flattered my expectation from thee? verses? poetrie? OVID, whom I thought to see the pleader, become OVID the play-maker?

sp.speaker: OVID iu.
sp.p: No, sir.

sp.speaker: OVID se.
sp.p: Yes, sir. I heare of a tragoedie of yours comming foorth for the common players there, call'd MEDEA. By my houshold-gods, if I come to the acting of it, Ile adde one tragick part, more then is yet expected, to it: beleeue me when I promise it. What? shall I haue my sonne a stager now? an enghle for players? a gull? a rooke? a shot-clogge? to make suppers, and bee laught at? PVBLIVS, I will set thee on the funerall pile, first.

sp.speaker: OVID iu.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you to haue patience.

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Nay, this tis to haue your eares damm'd vp to good counsell. I did augure all this to him afore-hand, without poring into an oxes panch for the matter, and yet he would not be scrupulous.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: How now, good man slaue? what, rowle powle? all riualls, rascall? why my Master, of worship, do'st heare? Are these thy best proiects? is this thy desseignes and thy discipline, to suffer knaues to bee competitors with commanders and gentlemen? are wee paralells, rascall? are wee paralells?

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Sirrah, goe get my horses ready. You'll still be prating.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Doe, you perpetuall stinkard, doe, goe, talke to tapsters and ostlers, you slaue, they are i' your element, goe: here bee the Emperours captaines, you raggamuffin rascall; and not your cam'rades.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: Indeed, MARCVS OVID, these players are an idle generation, and doe much harme in a state, corrupt yong gentrie very much, I know it: I haue not beene a Tribune thus long, and obseru'd nothing: besides, they will rob vs, vs, that are magistrates, of our respect, bring vs vpon their stages, and make vs ridiculous to the plebeians; they will play you, or me, the wisest men they can come by still; me: only to bring vs in contempt with the vulgar, and make vs cheape.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Th'art in the right, my venerable cropshin, they will indeede: the tongue of the oracle neuer twang'd truer. Your courtier cannot kisse his mistris slippers, in quiet, for 'hem: nor your white innocent gallant pawne his reuelling sute, to make his punke a supper. An honest decayed commander, cannot skelder, cheat, nor be seene in a bawdie house, but he shall be straight in one of their worme wood comoedies. They are growne licentious, the rogues; libertines, flat libertines. They forget they are i' the statute, the rascals, they are blazond there, there they are trickt, they and their pedigrees; they neede no other heralds, I wisse.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Mee thinkes, if nothing else, yet this alone, the very reading of the publike edicts should fright thee from commerce with them; and giue thee distaste enough of their actions. But this betrayes what a student you are: this argues your proficiencie in the law.

sp.speaker: OVID. iu.
sp.l: They wrong mee, sir, and doe abuse you more,
That blow your eares with these vntrue reports.
I am not knowne vnto the open stage,
Nor doe I traffique in their theaters.
Indeed, I doe acknowledge, at request
Of some neere friends, and honorable Romanes,
I haue begunne a poeme of that nature.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: You haue, sir, a poeme? and where is't? that's the law you studie.

sp.speaker: OVID. iu.
sp.p: CORNELIVS GALLVS borrowed it to reade.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p:
CORNELIVS GALLVS? There's another gallant, too, hath drunke of the same poison: and TIBVLLVS, and PROPERTIVS. But these are gentlemen of meanes, and reuenew now. Thou art a yonger brother, and hast nothing, but thy bare exhibition: which I protest shall bee bare indeed, if thou forsake not these vnprofitable by-courses, and that timely too. Name me a profest poet, that his poetrie did euer afford
him so much as a competencie. I, your god of poets there (whom all of you admire and reuerence so much) HOMER, he whose worme-eaten statue must not bee spewd against, but with hallowed lips, and groueling adoration, what was he? what was he?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Mary, I'le tell thee, old swagger; He was a poore, blind, riming rascall, that liu'd obscurely vp and downe in boothes, and tap-houses, and scarce euer made a good meale in his sleepe, the whoorson hungrie begger.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: He saies well: Nay, I know this nettles you now, but answere me; Is't not true? you'le tell me his name shall liue; and that (now being dead) his workes haue eternis'd him, and made him diuine But could this diuinitie feed him, while he liu'd? could his name feast him?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Or purchase him a Senators reuenue? could it?

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: I, or giue him place in the common-wealth? worship, or attendants? make him be carried in his litter?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Thou speakest sentences, old BIAS.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: All this the law will doe, yong sir, if youle follow it.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: If he be mine, hee shall follow and obserue, what I will apt him too, or, I professe here openly, and vtterly to disclaime in him.

sp.speaker: OVID. iu.
sp.l: Sir, let me craue you will, forgoe these moodes;
I will be any thing, or studie any thing:
I'le proue the vnfashion'd body of the law
Pure elegance, and make her ruggedst straines
Ruine smoothly, as PROPERTIVS elegies.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.l: PROPERTIVS elegies? good!

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.l: Nay, you take him too quickly, MARCVS.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Why, he cannot speake, he cannot thinke out of poetrie, he is bewitcht with it.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: Come, doe not mis-prize him.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Mis-prize? I, mary, I would haue him vse some such wordes now: They haue some touch, some taste of the law. Hee should make himselfe a stile out of these, and let his PROPERTIVS elegies goe by.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: Indeed, yong PVBLIVS, he that will now hit the marke, must shoot thorough the law we haue no other planet raignes, & in that spheare, you may sit, and sing with angels. Why, the law makes a man happy, without respecting any other merit: a simple scholer, or none at all may be a lawyer.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: He tells thee true, my noble Neophyte; my little Grammaticaster, he do's: It shall neuer put thee to thy Mathematiques, Metaphysiques, Philosophie, and I know not what suppos'd sufficiencies; If thou canst but haue the patience to plod inough, talke, and make noise inough, be impudent inough, and 'tis inough.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: Three bookes will furnish you.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: And the lesse arte, the better: Besides, when it shall be in the power of thy cheu'rill conscience, to doe right, or wrong, at thy pleasure, my pretty ALCIBIADES.

sp.speaker: LVPV.
sp.p: I, and to haue better men then himselfe, by many thousand degrees, to obserue him, and stand bare.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: True, and he to carry himselfe proud, and stately, and haue the law on his side for't, old boy.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Well, the day growes old, gentlemen, and I must leaue you. PVBLIVS, if thou wilt hold my fauour, abandon these idle fruitlesse studies that so bewitch thee. Send IANVS home his back-face againe, and looke only forward to the law: Intend that. I will allow thee, what shall sute thee in the ranke of gentlemen, and maintaine thy societie with the best: and vnder these conditions, I leaue thee. My blessings light vpon thee, if thou respect them: if not, mine eyes may drop for thee, but thine owne heart wil ake for it selfe; and so farewel. What, are my horses come?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Yes, sir, they are at the gate without.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: That's well. ASINIVS LVPVS, a word. Captaine, I shall take my leaue of you?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: No, my little old boy, dispatch with COTHVRNVS there: I'le attend thee, I—

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: To borrow some ten drachmes, I know his proiect.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Sir, you shall make me beholding to you. Now Captaine TVCCA, what say you?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Why, what should I say? or what can I say, my flowre o' the order? Should I say, thou art rich? or that thou art honorable? or wise? or valiant? or learned? or liberall? Why, thou art all these, and thou knowest it (my noble LVCVLLVS) thou knowest it: come, bee not ashamed of thy vertues, old stumpe. Honour's a good brooch to weare in a mans hat, at all times. Thou art the man of warres MECOENAS, old boy. Why shouldst not thou bee grac't then by them, as well as hee is by his poets? How now, my carrier, what newes?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: The boy has staied within for his cue, this halfe houre.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Come, doe not whisper to me, but speake it out: what? it is no treason against the state, I hope, is't?

sp.speaker: LVSC.
sp.p: Yes, against the state of my masters purse.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: Sir, AGRIPPA desires you to forbeare him till the next weeke: his moyles are not yet come vp.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: His moyles? now the bots, the spauin, and the glanders, and some dozen diseases more, light on him, and his moyles. What ha' they the yellowes, his moyles, that they come no faster? or are they foundred? ha? his moyles ha' the staggers belike: ha' they?

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: O no, sir: then your tongue might be suspected for one of his moyles.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p:
Hee owes mee almost a talent, and hee thinks to beare it away with his moyles, does hee? Sirrah, you, nut-cracker, goe your waies to him againe, and tell him I must ha' money, I: I cannot eate stones and turses, say. What, will he clem me, and my followers? Aske him, an' he will clem me: doe, goe. He would haue mee frie my ierkin, would hee?
Away, setter, away. Yet, stay, my little tumbler: this old boy shall supply now. I will not trouble him, I cannot bee importunate, I: I cannot bee impudent.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: Alas, sir, no: you are the most maidenly blushing creature vpon the earth.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Do'st thou heare, my little sixe and fiftie, or thereabouts? Thou art not to learne the humours and tricks of that old bald cheater, Time: thou hadst not this chaine for nothing. Men of worth haue their chymaera's, as well as other creatures: and they doe see monsters, sometimes: they doe, they doe, braue boy.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: Better cheape then he shall see you, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Thou must let me haue sixe, sixe, drachmes, I meane, old boy; thou shalt doe it: I tell thee, old boy, thou shalt, and in priuate too, do'st thou see? Goe, walke off: there, there. Sixe is the summe. Thy sonn's a gallant sparke, and must not be put out of a sudden: come hither, CALLINACHVS, thy father tells me thou art too poeticall, boy, thou must not be so, thou must leaue them, yong nouice, thou must, they are a sort of poore staru'd rascalls; that are euer wrapt vp in foule linnen; and can boast of nothing but a leane visage, peering out of a seame-rent sute; the very emblemes of beggerie. No, dost heare? turne lawyer, Thou shalt be my solicitor: Tis right, old boy, ist?

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: You were best tell it, Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: No: fare thou well mine honest horse-man, and thou old beuer. Pray thee Romane, when thou commest to towne, see me at my lodging, visit me sometimes: thou shalt be welcome, old boy. Doe not balke me, good swaggerer. IOVE keepe thy chaine from pawning, goe thy waies, if thou lack money, I'le lend thee some: I'le leaue thee to thy horse, now. Adieu.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: Farewell, good Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Boy, you can haue but halfe a share now, boy.

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange boldnesse, that accompanies this fellow: Come.

sp.speaker: OVID. iu.
sp.p: I'le giue attendance on you, to your horse, sir, please you—

sp.speaker: OVID. se.
sp.p: No: keepe your chamber, and fall to your studies; doe so: the gods of Rome blesse thee.

sp.speaker: OVID. iu.
sp.l: And giue me stomacke to digest this law,
That should haue followed sure, had I beene he.
O sacred poesie, thou spirit of artes,
The soule of science, and the queene of soules,
What prophane violence, almost sacriledge,
Hath here beene offered thy diuinities!
That thine owne guiltlesse pouertie should arme
Prodigious ignorance to wound thee thus!
For thence, is all their force of argument
Drawne forth against thee; or from the abuse
Of thy great powers in adultrate braines:
When, would men learne but to distinguish spirits,
And set true difference twixt those jaded wits
That runne a broken pase for common hire,
And the high raptures of a happy Muse
Borne on the wings of her immortall thought,
That kickes at earth with a disdainefull heele,
And bears at heauen gates with her bright hooues;
They would not then with such distorted faces,
And desp'rate censures stab at poesie.
They would admire bright knowledge, and their minds
Should ne're descend on so vnworthy obiects,
As gold, or titles: they would dread farre more,
To be thought ignorant, then be knowne poore.
"The time was once, when wit drown'd wealth: but now,
" Your onely barbarisme is t'haue wit, and want.
"No matter now in vertue who excells,
" He, that hath coine, hath all perfection else.
OVID?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Who's there? Come in.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Good morrow, Lawyer.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Good morrow (deare TIBVLLVS) welcome: sit downe.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Not I. What: so hard at it? Let's see, what's here?
Nay, I will see it—

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Pray thee away—

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: If thrice in field, a man vanquish his foe,
'Tis after in his choice to serue, or no.
How now OVID! Law— cases in verse?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: In troth, I know not: they runne from my pen
Vnwittingly, if they be verse. What's the newes abroad?

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Off with this gowne, I come to haue thee walke.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: No, good TIBVLLVS, I'm not now in case,
Pray' let me alone.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: How? not in case!
S'light thou'rt in too much case, by all this law.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Troth, if I liue, I will new dresse the law,
In sprightly poesies habillaments.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: The hell thou wilt. What, turne law into verse?
Thy father has school'd thee, I see. Here, reade that same.
There's subiect for you: and if I mistake not,
A Supersedeas to your melancholy.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: How! subscrib'd IVLIA! Ô, my life, my heauen!

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Is the mood chang'd?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Musique of wit! Note for th' harmonious spheares!
Celestiall accents, how you rauish me!

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: What is it, OVID?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: That I must meete my IVLIA, the Princesse IVLIA.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Why, at— hart, I haue forgot: my passion so transports mee.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Ile saue your paines: it is at ALBIVS house,
The iewellers, where the faire LYCORIS lies.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Who? CYTHERIS, CORNELIVS GALLVS loue?

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: I, heele be there too, and my PLAVTIA.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: And why not your DELIA?

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Yes, and your CORINNA.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: True, but my sweet TIBVLLVS, keepe that secret:
I would not, for all ROME, it should be thought,
I vaile bright IVLIA vnderneath that name:
IVLIA the gemme, and iewell of my soule,
That takes her honours from the golden skie,
As beautie doth all lustre, from her eye.
The ayre respires the pure elyzian sweets,
In which she breathes: and from her lookes descend
The glories of the summer. Heauen she is,
Prays'd in her selfe aboue all praise: and he,
Which heares her speake, would sweare the tune-full orbes
Turn'd in his zenith onely.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: PVBLIVS, thou'lt lose thy selfe.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: O, in no labyrinth, can I safelier erre,
Then when I lose my selfe in praysing her.
Hence Law, and welcome, Muses; though not rich,
Yet are you pleasing: let's be reconcilde,
And now made one. Hencefoorth, I promise faith,
And all my serious houres to spend with you:
With you, whose musicke striketh on my heart,
And with bewitching tones steales forth my spirit,
In IVLIAS name; faire IVLIA: IVLIAS loue
Shall be a law, and that sweet law I'le studie,
The law, and art of sacred IVLIAS loue:
All other obiects will but abiects prooue.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: Come, wee shall haue thee as passionate, as PROPERTIVS, anon.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: O, how does my SEXTVS?

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: Faith, full of sorrow, for his CYNTHIAS death.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: What, still?

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Still, and still more, his grieues doe grow vpon him,
As doe his houres. Neuer did I know
An vnderstanding spirit so take to heart
The common worke of fate.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: O my TIBVLLVS,
Let vs not blame him: for, against such chances,
The heartiest strife of vertue is not proofe.
We may read constancie, and fortitude,
To other soules: but had our selues beene strooke
With the like planet, had our loues (like his)
Beene rauisht from vs, by injurious death,
And in the height, and heat of our best dayes,
It would haue crackt our sinnewes, shrunke our veines,
And made our verie heart-strings iarre, like his.
Come, let's goe take him foorth, and prooue, if mirth
Or companie will but abate his passion.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: Content, and I implore the gods, it may.

sp.p: MAster CRISPINVS, you are welcome: Pray', vse a stoole, sir. Your cousin CYTHERIS will come downe presently. Wee are so busie for the receiuing of these courtiers here, that I can scarce be a minute with my selfe, for thinking of them: Pray you sit, sir, Pray you sit, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I am verie well, sir. Ne're trust me, but you are most delicately seated here, full of sweet delight and blandishment! an excellent ayre, an excellent ayre!

sp.speaker: ALEI.
sp.p: I, sir, 'tis prettie ayre. These courtiers runne in my minde still; I must looke out: for IVPITERS sake, sit, sir. Or please you walke into the garden? There's a garden on the back-side.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I am most strenuously well, I thanke you, sir.

sp.speaker: ALEI.
sp.p: Much good doe you, sir.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Come, bring those perfumes forward a little, and strew some roses, and violets here; Fye, here bee roomes sauour the most pittifully ranke that euer I felt: I crie the gods mercie, my husband's in the winde of vs.

sp.speaker: ALEI.
sp.p: Why, this is good, excellent, excellent: well said, my sweet CHLOE. Trimme vp your house most obsequiously.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: For VVLCANVS sake, breathe somewhere else: in troth you ouercome our perfumes exceedingly, you are too predominant.

sp.speaker: ALEI.
sp.p: Heare but my opinion, sweet wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: A pinne for your pinnion. In sinceritie, if you be thus fulsome to me in euerie thing, I'le bee diuore't; God's my bodie? you know what you were, before I married you; I was a gentlewoman borne, I; I lost all my friends to be a citizens wife; because I heard indeed, they kept their wiues as fine as ladies; and that wee might rule our husbands, like ladies; and doe what wee listed: doe you thinke I would haue married you, else?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: I acknowledge, sweet wife, she speakes the best of any woman in Italy, and mooues as mightily: which makes me, I had rather she should make bumpes on my head, as big as my two singers, then I would offend her. But sweet wife—

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Yet againe? I'st not grace inough for you, that I call you husband, and you call me wife: but you must still bee poking mee, against my will, to things?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: But you know, wife; here are the greatest ladies, and gallantest gentlemen of ROME, to bee entertain'd in our house now: and I would faine aduise thee, to entertaine them in the best sort, yfaith wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: In sinceritie, did you euer heare a man talke so idlely? You would seeme to be master? You would haue your spoke in my cart? you would aduise me to entertaine ladies, and gentlemen? because you can marshall your pack-needles, horse-combes, hobby-horses, and wall-candlestickes in your ware-house better then I; therefore you can tell how to entertaine ladies, and gentle-folkes better then I?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: O my sweet wife, vpbraid me not with that: "Gaine sauours sweetly from any thing; He that respects to get, must relish all commodities alike; and admit no difference betwixt oade, and frankincense; or the most precious balsamum, and a tar-barrell.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Mary fough: You sell snuffers too, if you be remembred, but I pray you let mee buy them out of your hand; for I tell you true, I take it highly in snuffe, to learne how to entertaine gentlefolkes, of you, at these yeeres, I faith. Alas man; there was not a gentleman came to your house i' your tother wiues time, I hope? nor a ladie? nor musique? nor masques? Nor you, nor your house were so much as spoken of, before I disbast my selfe, from my hood and my fartingall, to these bumrowles, and your whale-bone-bodies.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Looke here, my sweet wife; I am mum, my deare mummia, my balsamum, my spermacete, and my verie citie of— shee has the most best, true, feminine wit in ROME!

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I haue heard so, sir; and doe most vehemently desire to participate the knowledge of her faire features.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Ah, peace; you shall heare more anon: bee not seene yet, I pray you; not yet: Obserue.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: 'Sbodie, giue husbands the head a little more, and they'll bee nothing but head shortly; what's he there?

sp.speaker: MAYD. 1.
sp.p: I know not forsooth.

sp.speaker: MAYD. 2.
sp.p: Who would you speake with, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I would speake with my cousin CYTHERIS.

sp.speaker: MAYD.
sp.p: Hee is one forsooth would speake with his cousin CYTHERIS.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Is she your cousin, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Yes in truth, forsooth, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Shee is a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Or else she should not be my cousin, I assure you.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Are you a gentleman borne?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: That I am, ladie; you shall see mine armes, if 't please you.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: No, your legges doe sufficiently shew you are a gentleman borne, sir: for a man borne vpon little legges, is alwayes a gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Yet, I pray you, vouchsafe the sight of my armes, Mistresse; for I beare them about me, to haue 'hem seene: my name is CRISPINVS, or CRI-SPINAS indeed; which is well exprest in my armes, (a Face crying in chiefe; and beneath it a blouddie Toe, betweene three Thornes pungent.)

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Then you are welcome, sir; now you are a gentleman borne, I can find in my heart to welcome you: for I am a gentlewoman borne too; and will beare my head high inough, though 'twere my fortune to marrie a trades-man.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: No doubt of that, sweet feature, your carriage shewes it in any mans eye, that is carried vpon you with iudgement.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Hee is still going in and out. Deare wife, be not angry.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: God's my passion!

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Heare me but one thing; let not your maydes set cushions in the parlor windowes; nor in the dyning-chamber windowes; nor vpon stooles, in eyther of them, in any case; for 'tis tauerne-like; but lay them one vpon another, in some out-roome, or corner of the dyning-chamber.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Goe, goe, meddle with your bed-chamber onely, or rather with your bed in your chamber, onely; or rather with your wife in your bed onely; or on my faith, I'le not be pleas'd with you onely.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Looke here, my deare wife, entertaine that gentleman kindly, I pre' thee,— mum.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Goe, I need your instructions indeede; anger mee no more, I aduise you. Citi-sin, quoth'a! she's a wise gentlewoman yfaith, will marrie her selfe to the sinne of the citie.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: But this time, and no more (by heauen) wife: hang no pictures in the hall, nor in the dyning-chamber, in any case, but in the gallerie onely, for 'tis not courtly else, o' my word, wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: 'Sprecious, neuer haue done!

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Wife.—

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Doe I not beare a reasonable corrigible hand ouer him, CRISPINVS?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: By this hand, ladie, you hold a most sweet hand ouer him.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: And then for the great gilt andyrons?—

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Againe! would the andyrons were in your great guttes, for mee.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: I doe vanish, wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p:
How shall I doe, Master CRISPINVS? here will bee all the brauest ladies in court presently, to see your cousin CYTHERIS: Ô the
gods! how might I behaue my selfe now, as to entertayne them most courtly?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Mary, ladie, if you will entertaine them most courtly, you must doe thus: as soone as euer your maide, or your man brings you word they are come; you must say (A poxe on 'hem, what doe they here.) And yet when they come, speake them as faire, and giue them the kindest welcome in wordes, that can be.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Is that the fashion of courtiers, CRISPINVS?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I assure you, it is, ladie, I haue obseru'd it.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: For your poxe, sir, it is easily hit on; but, 'tis not so easily to speake faire after, me thinkes?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: O wife, the coaches are come, on my word, a number of coaches, and courtiers.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: A poxe on them: what doe they here?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: How now wife! wouldst thou not haue 'hem come?

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Come? come, you are a foole, you: He knowes not the trick on't. Call CYTHERIS, I pray you: and good master CRISPINVS, you can obserue, you say; let me intreat you for all the ladies behauiours, iewels, iests, and attires, that you marking as well as I, we may put both our markes together, when they are gone, and conferre of them.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I warrant you, sweet ladie; let mee alone to obserue, till I turne my selfe to nothing but obseruation. Good morrow cousin CYTHERIS.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: Welcome kind cousin. What? are they come?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: I, your friend CORNELIVS GALLVS, OVID, TIBVLLVS, PROPERTIVS, with IVLIA the Emperors daughter, and the ladie PLAVTIA, are lighted at the dore; and with them HERMOGENES TIGELLIVS, the excellent musician.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: Come, let vs goe meet them, CHLOE.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Obserue, CRISPINVS.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: At a haires breadth, ladie, I warrant you.

div.head: Act II. Scene II.
div.stage: GALLVS, OVID, TIBVLLVS, PROPERTIVS, HERMOGENES, IVLIA, PLAVTIA, CYTHERIS, CHLOE, ALBIVS, CRISPINVS.

sp.p: HEalth to the louely CHLOE: you must pardon me, Mistris, that I preferre this faire gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: I pardon, and praise you for it, sir; and I beseech your Excellence, receiue her beauties into your knowledge and fauour.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p:
CYTHERIS, shee hath fauour, and behauiour, that commands as much of me: and sweet CHLOE, know I doe exceedingly loue you, and
that I will approue in any grace my father the Emperour may shew you. Is this your husband?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: For fault of a better, if it please your highnesse.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Gods my life! how hee shames mee!

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: Not a whit, CHLOE, they all thinke you politike, and wittie; wise women choose not husbands for the eye, merit, or birth, but wealth, and soueraigntie.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Sir, we all come to gratulate, for the good report of you.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: And would be glad to deserue your loue, sir.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: My wife will answere you all, gentlemen; I'le come to you againe presently.

sp.speaker: PLAV.
sp.p: You haue chosen you a most faire companion here, CYTHERIS, and a very faire house.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: To both which, you and all my friends, are very welcome, PLAVTIA.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: With all my heart, I assure your ladiship.

sp.speaker: PLAV.
sp.p: Thankes, sweet Mistris CHLOE.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: You must needes come to court, ladie, yfaith, and there bee sure your welcome shall be as great to vs.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Shee will well deserue it, Madame. I see, euen in her lookes, gentrie, and generall worthinesse.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: I haue not seene a more certaine character of an excellent disposition.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: O, they doe so commend me here, the courtiers! what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: For the banquet, sweet wife.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Yes; and I must needs come to court, and bee welcome, the Princesse sayes.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: OVID, and TIBVLLVS, you may bee bold to welcome your Mistresses here.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: We find it so, sir.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: And thanke CORNELIVS GALLVS.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: Nay, my sweet SEXTVS, in faith thou art not sociable.

sp.speaker: PROP.
sp.l: In faith, I am not, PVBLIVS; nor I cannot.
Sicke mindes, are like sicke men that burne with feuers,
Who when they drinke, please but a present tast,
And after beare a more impatient fit.
Pray, let me leaue you; I offend you all,
And my selfe most.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.l: Stay, sweet PROPERTIVS.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.l: You yeeld too much vnto your grieues, and sate,
Which neuer hurts, but when we say it hurts vs.

sp.speaker: PROP.
sp.l: O peace, TIBVLLVS; your philosophie
Lends you too rough a hand to search my wounds.
Speake they of griefes, that know to sigh, and grieue;
The free and vnconstrained spirit feeles
No weight of my oppression.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: Worthy Roman!
Me thinkes I taste his miserie; and could
Sit downe, and chide at his malignant starres.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.l: Me thinkes I loue him, that he loues so truely.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.l: This is the perfect'st loue, liues after death.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.l: Such is the constant ground of vertue still.

sp.speaker: PLAV.
sp.l: It puts on an inseparable face.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.l: Haue you markt euery thing, CRISPINVS?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Euery thing, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.l: What gentlemen are these? doe you know them?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: I, they are poets, lady.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.l: Poets? they did not talke of me since I went, did they?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: O yes, and extold your perfections to the heauens.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Now in sinceritie, they be the finest kind of men, that euer I knew: Poets? Could not one get the Emperour to make my husband a Poet, thinke you?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: No, ladie, 'tis loue, and beautie make Poets: and since you like Poets so well, your loue, and beauties shall make me a Poet.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: What shall they? and such a one as these?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I, and a better then these: I would be sorry else.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: And shall your lookes change? and your haire change? and all, like these?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Why, a man may be a Poet, and yet not change his haire, lady.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Well, wee shall see your cunning: yet if you can change your haire, I pray, doe.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Ladies, and lordings, there's a slight banquet staies within for you, please you draw neere, and accost it.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: We thanke you, good ALBIVS: but when shall wee see those excellent iewels you are commended to haue?

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: At your ladiships seruice. I got that speech by seeing a play last-day, and it did me some grace now: I see, 'tis good to collect sometimes; I'le frequent these plaies more then I haue done, now I come to be familiar with courtiers.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: Why, how now, HERMOGENES? what ailest thou trow?

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: A little melancholy, let me alone, pray thee.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: Melancholy! how so?

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: With riding: a plague on all coaches for me.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: Is that hard-fauour'd gentleman a poet too; CYTHERIS?

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: No; this is HERMOGENES, as humorous as a poet though: he is at Musician.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: A Musician? then he can sing.

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p: That he can excellently; did you neuer heare him?

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: O no: will he be intreated, thinke you?

sp.speaker: CYTH.
sp.p:
I know not. Friend, Mistresse CHLOE would faine heare
HERMOGENES sing: are you interested in him?

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: No doubt, his owne humanitie will command him so farre, to the satisfaction of so faire a beautie; but rather then faile, weele all bee suiters to him.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: Cannot sing.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: Pray thee, HERMOGENES.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: 'Cannot sing.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: For honour of this gentlewoman, to whose house, I know thou maist be euer welcome.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: That he shall in truth, sir, if he can sing.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: This gentlewoman is wooing HERMOGENES for a song.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: A song? come, he shall not denie her. HERMOGENES?

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: 'Cannot sing.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: No, the ladies must doe it, hee staies but to haue their thankes acknowledg'd as a debt to his cunning.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: That shall not want: our selfe will be the first shall promise to pay him more then thankes, vpon a fauour so worthily vouchsaft.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: Thanke you, Madame, but 'will not sing.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: Tut, the onely way to winne him, is to abstaine from intreating him.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Doe you loue singing, ladie?

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: O, passingly.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Intreat the ladies, to intreat me to sing then, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: I beseech your grace, intreat this gentleman to sing.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: That we will CHLOE; can he sing excellently?

sp.speaker: CHLO.
sp.p: I thinke so, Madame: for he intreated me, to intreat you, to intreat him to sing.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Heauen, and earth! would you tell that?

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: Good sir, let's intreat you to vse your voice.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Alas, Madame, I cannot in truth.

sp.speaker: PLAV.
sp.p: The gentleman is modest: I warrant you, he sings excellently.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: HERMOGENES, cleere your throat: I see by him, here's a gentleman will worthily challenge you.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Not I, sir, I'le challenge no man.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: That's your modestie, sir: but wee, out of an assurance of your excellencie, challenge him in your behalfe.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I thanke you, gentlemen, I'le doe my best.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: Let that best be good, sir, you were best.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: O, this contention is excellent. What is't you sing, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: If I freely may discouer, &c. Sir, I'le sing that.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.l: One of your owne compositions, HERMOGENES.
He offers you vantage enough.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Nay truely, gentlemen, I'le challenge no man—: I can sing but one staffe of the dittie neither.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: The better: HERMOGENES himselfe will bee intreated to sing the other.
sp.l: IF I freely may discouer,
What would please me in my louer:
I would haue her faire, and wittie,
Sauouring more of court, then cittie;
A little proud, but full of pittie:
Light, and humorous in her toying.
Oft building hopes, and soone destroying,
Long, but sweet in the enioying,
Neither too easie, nor too hard:
All extremes I would haue bard.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: Beleeue me, sir, you sing most excellently.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: If there were a praise aboue excellence, the gentleman highly deserues it.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: Sir, all this doth not yet make mee enuie you: for I know I sing better then you.

sp.speaker: TIBV.
sp.p: Attend HERMOGENES, now.
sp.l: Shee should be allowed her passions,
So they were but vs'd as fashions;
Sometimes froward, and then frowning,
Sometimes sickish, and then swowning,
Euery fit, with change, still crowning.
Purely iealous, I would haue her,
Then onely constant when I craue her.
'Tis a vertue should not saue her.
Thus, nor her delicates would cloy me,
Neither her peeuishnesse annoy me.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: Nay, HERMOGENES, your merit hath long since beene both knowne, and admir'd of vs.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: You shall heare me sing another: now will I begin.

sp.speaker: GALL.
sp.p: We shall doe this gentlemans banquet too much wrong, that staies for vs, ladies.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: 'Tis true: and well thought on, CORNELIVS GALLVS.

sp.speaker: HERM.
sp.p: Why 'tis but a short aire, 'twill be done presently, pray' stay; strike musique.

sp.speaker: OVID.
sp.p: No, good HERMOGENES: wee'll end this difference within.

sp.speaker: IVLI.
sp.p: 'Tis the common disease of all your musicians, hat they know no meane, to be intreated, either to begin, or end.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Please you lead the way, gentles?

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Thankes, good ALBIVS.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: O, what a charme of thankes was here put vpon me! O IOVE, what a setting forth it is to a man, to haue many courtiers come to his house! Sweetly was it said of a good olde house-keeper; I had rather want meate, then want ghests: specially, if they be courtly ghests. For, neuer trust me, if one of their good legges made in a house, be not worth all the good cheere, a man can make them. Hee that would haue fine ghests, let him haue a fine wife; he that would haue a fine wife, let him come to me.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: By your kind leaue, Master ALBIVS.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: What, you are not gone, Master CRISPINVS?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Yes faith, I haue a desseigne drawes me hence: pray' sir, fashion mean excuse to the ladies.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Will you not stay? and see the iewels, sir? I pay you stay.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Not for a million, sir, now; Let it suffice, I must relinquish; and so in a word, please you to expiate this complement.

sp.speaker: ALBI.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: He presently goe and enghle some broker, for a Poets gowne, and bespeake a garland: and then ieweller, looke to your best iewell yfaith.
Hot. li. 1. Sat. 9 HMh? yes; I will begin an ode so: and it shall be to MECOENAS.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: 'Slid, yonder's HORACE! they say hee's an excellent Poet: MECOENAS loues him. Ile fall into his acquaintance, if I can; I thinke he be composing, as he goes i' the street! ha? 't is a good humour, and he be: Ile compose too.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Swell me a bowle with lustie wine,
Till I may see the plump LYaeVS swim
Aboue the brim:
I drinke, as I would wright,
In slowing measure, fill'd with flame, and spright.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Sweet HORACE, MINERVA, and the Muses stand auspicious to thy desseignes. How far'st thou, sweete man? frolicke? rich? gallant? ha?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Not greatly gallant, sir, like my fortunes; well.
I'm bold to take my leaue, sir, you'ld naught else, sir, would you?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Troth, no, but I could wish thou did'st know vs, HORACE, we are a scholer, I assure thee.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: A scholer, sir? I shall bee couetous of your faire knowledge.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Gramercie, good HORACE. Nay, we are new turn'd Poet too, which is more; and a Satyrist too, which is more then that: I write iust in thy veine, I. I am for your odes or your sermons, or any thing indeed; wee are a gentleman besides: our name is RVFVS LABERIVS CRISPINVS, weare a prettie stoick too.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: To the proportion of your beard, I thinke it, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: By PHOEBVS, here's a most neate fine street, is't not? I protest to thee, I am enamour'd of this street now, more then of halfe the streets of some, againe; 'tis so polite, and terse! There's the front of a building now. I studie architecture too: if euer I should build, I'de haue a house iust of that prospectiue.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Doubtlesse, this gallants tongue has a good turne, when hee sleepes.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I doe make verses, when I come in such a street as this: O your city-ladies, you shall ha'hem sit in euery shop like the Muses— offring you the castalian dewes, and the thespian liquors, to as many as haue but the sweet grace and audacitie to— sip of their lips. Did you neuer heare any of my verses?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: No, sir (but I am in some feare, I must, now.)

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I'le tell thee some (if I can but recouer 'hem) I compos'd e'en now of a dressing, I saw a iewellers wife weare, who indeede was a iewell herselfe: I preferre that kind of tire now, what's thy opinion, HORACE?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: With your siluer bodkin, it does well, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I cannot tell, but it stirres me more then all your court-curles, or your spangles, or your tricks: I affect not these high gable-ends, these tuscane-tops, nor your coronets, nor your arches, nor your pyramids; giue me a fine sweet— little delicate dressing, with a bodkin, as you say: and a mushrome, for all your other ornatures.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Is't not possible to make an escape from him?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I haue remitted my verses, all this while, I thinke I ha' forget 'hem.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Here's he, could wish you had else.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Pray IOVE, I can intreat 'hem of my memorie.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: You put your memorie to too much trouble, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: No, sweet HORACE, we must not ha' thee thinke so.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: I crie you mercy; then, they are my eares
That must be tortur'd: well, you must haue patience, eares.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Pray thee, HORACE, obserue.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Yes, sir: your sattin sleeue begins to fret at the rug that is vnderneath it, I doe obserue: And your ample veluet bases are not without euident staines of a hot disposition, naturally.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: O— I'le die them into another colour, at pleasure: how many yards of veluet dost thou thinke they containe?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Hart! I haue put him now in a fresh way
To vexe me more: Faith, sir, your mercers booke
Will tell you with more patience, then I can;
(For I am crost, and so's not that, I thinke.)

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: S'light, these verses haue lost me againe: I shall not inuite 'hem to mind, now.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Racke not your thoughts, good sir; rather, deferre it
To a new time; I'le meete you at your lodging,
Or where you please: Till then, IOVE keepe you, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Nay, gentle HORACE, stay: I haue it, now.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Yes, sir. APOLLO, HERMES, IVPITER, looke down vpon me.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Rich was thy hap, sweet, deintie cap,
There to be placed:
Where thy smooth blacke, sleeke white may smacke,
And both be graced.
sp.p: white, is there vsurpt for her brow; her forehead: and then sleeke, as the paralell to smooth, that went before. A kind of Paranomasie, or Agnomination: doe you conceiue, sir?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Excellent. Troth, sir, I must be abrupt, and leaue you.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Why, what haste hast thou? pray thee, stay a little: thou shalt not goe yet, by PHOEBVS.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: I shall not? what remedie? Fie, how I sweat with suffering!

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: And then—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Pray, sir, giue me leaue to wipe my face a little.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Yes, doe, good HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Thanke you, sir.
Death! I must craue his leaue to pisse anon;
Or that I may goe hence with halfe my teeth:
I am in some such feare. This tyrannie
Is strange, to take mine eares vp by commission,
(Whether I will or no) and make them stalls
To his lewd soloecismes, and worded trash.
Happy thou, bold BOLANVS, now, I say;
Whose freedome, and impatience of this fellow,
Would, long ere this, haue call'd him foole, and foole,
And ranke, and tedious foole, and haue flung iests
As hard as stones, till thou hadst pelted him
Out of the place: whil'st my tame modestie
Suffers my wit be made a solemne asse
To beare his fopperies—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: HORACE, thou art miserably affected to be gone, I see. But— pray thee, let's proue, to enioy thee awhile: Thou hast no businesse, I assure me. Whether is thy iourney directed? ha?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Sir, I am going to visit a friend, that's sicke.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: A friend? What's he? doe not I know him?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: No, sir, you doe not know him; and 'tis not the worse for him.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: What's his name? where's he lodg'd?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Where, I shall be fearefull to draw you out of your way, sir; a great way hence: Pray', sir, let's part.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Nay, but where is't? I pray thee, say.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: On the farre side of all Tyber yonder, by CAESARS gardens.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: O, that's my course directly; I am for you. Come, goe: why stand'st thou?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Yes, sir: marry, the plague is in that part of the citie; I had almost forgot to tell you, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Fow: It's no matter, I feare no pestilence, I ha' not offended PHOEBVS.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: I haue, it seemes; or else this heauie scourge
Could ne're haue lighted on me—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Come, along.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: I am to goe downe some halfe mile, this way, sir, first, to speake with his physician: And from thence to his apothecary, where I shall stay the mixing of diuers drugs—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Why, it's all one. I haue nothing to doe, and I loue not to be idle, I'le beare thee companie. How call'st thou the pothecary?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: O, that I knew a name would fright him now. Sir RHADAMANTHVS, RHADAMANTHVS, sir.
There's one so cald, is a iust iudge, in hell,
And doth inflict strange vengeance on all those,
That (here on earth) torment poore patient spirits.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: He dwells at the three Faries, by IANVS Temple?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Your pothecary does, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Hart, I owe him money for sweet meates, and hee has laid to arrest me, I heare: but—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Sir, I haue made a most solemne vow: I will neuer baile any man.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Well then, I'le sweare, and speake him faire, if the worst come. But his name is MINOS, not RHADAMANTHVS, HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: That may bee, sir: I but guest at his name by his signe. But your MINOS is a iudge too, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I protest to thee, HORACE (doe but taste mee once) if I doe know my selfe, and mine owne vertues truely, thou wilt not make that esteeme of VARIVS, or VIRGIL, or TIBVLLVS, or any of 'hem indeed, as now in thy ignorance thou dost; which I am content to forgiue: I would faine see, which of these could pen more verses in a day, or with more facilitie then I; or that could court his mistris, kisse her hand, make better sport with her fanne, or her dogge—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: I cannot baile you yet, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Or that could moue his body more gracefully, or dance better you shoo'd see mee, were it not i' the street—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Nor yet.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Why, I haue beene a reueller, and at my cloth of siluer sute, and my long stocking, in my time, and will be againe—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: If you may be trusted, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: And then for my singing, HERMOGENES himselfe enuies me; that is your onely Master of musique you haue in Rome.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Is your mother liuing, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Au: Conuert thy thoughts to somewhat else, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: You haue much of the mother in you, sir: your father is dead?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I, I thanke IOVE, and my grand-father too and all my kinsfolkes, and well compos'd in their vrnes.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: The more their happinesse; that rest in peace,
Free from th'abundant torture of thy tongue;
Would I were with them too.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: What's that, HORACE?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: I now remember me, sir, of a sad fate
A cunning woman, one SABELLA sung,
When in her vrne, she cast my destinie,
I being but a child

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: What was't I pray thee?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Shee told me, I should surely neuer perish
By famine, poyson, or the enemies sword;
The hecticke feuer, cough, or pleurisie,
Should neuer hurt me; nor the tardie gowt:
But in my time, I should be once surpriz'd,
By a strong tedious talker, that should vexe
And almost bring me to consumption.
Therefore (if I were wise) she warn'd me shunne
All such long-winded monsters, as my bane:
For if I could but scape that one discourser,
I might (no doubt) proue an olde aged man.
By your leaue, sir?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Tut, tut: abandon this idle humour, 'tis nothing but melancholy. Fore IOVE, now I thinke ont, I am to appeare in court here, to answere to one that has me in suit; sweet HORACE, goe with mee, this is my houre: if I neglect it, the law proceedes against me. Thou art familiar with these things, pray thee, if thou lou'st me, goe.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Now, let me dye, sir, if I know your lawes;
Or haue the power to stand still halfe so long
In their loud courts, as while a case is Argued.
Besides, you know, sir, where I am to goe,
And the necessitie—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: 'Tis true:—

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: I hope the houre of my release be come: Hee will (vpon this consideration) discharge me, sure.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Troth, I am doubtfull, what I may best doe; whether to leaue thee, or my affaires, HORACE?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: O IVPITER, mee, sir; mee, by any meanes: I beseech you, mee, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: No saith, I'le venture those now: Thou shalt see I loue thee, come HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p:
Nay then, I am desperate: I follow you, sir. 'Tis hard
contending with a man that ouer-comes thus.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: And how deales MECOENAS with thee? liberally? ha?
Is he open-handed? bountifull?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Hee's still himselfe, sir.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Troth, HORACE, thou art exceeding happy in thy friends and acquaintance; they are all most choice spirits, and of the first ranke of Romanes: I doe not know that poet, I protest, ha's vs'd his fortune more prosperously, then thou hast. If thou would'st bring me knowne to MECoeNAS, I should second thy desert well; thou should'st find a good sure assistant of mee: one, that would speake all good of thee in thy absence, and be content with the next place, not enuying thy reputation with thy patron. Let me not liue, but I thinke thou and I (in a small time) should list them all out of fauour, both VIRGIL, VARIVS, and the best of them; and enioy him wholy to our selues.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Gods, you doe know it, I can hold no longer;
This brize hath prickt my patience: Sir, your silkenesse
Cleerely mistakes MECOENAS, and his house;
To thinke, there breathes a spirit beneath his roofe,
Subiect vnto those poore affections
Of vnder-mining enuie, and detraction,
Moodes, onely proper to base groueling minds:
That place is not in Rome, I dare affirme,
More pure, or free, from such low common euils.
There's no man greeu'd, that this is thought more rich,
Or this more learned; each man hath his place,
And to his merit, his reward of grace:
Which with a mutuall loue they all embrace.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: You report a wonder! 'tis scarce credible, this.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: I am no torture, to enforce you to beleeue it, but 'tis so.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Why, this enflames mee with a more ardent desire to bee his, then before: but, I doubt I shall find the entrance, to his familiaritie, somwhat more then difficult, HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Tut, you'le conquer him, as you haue done me; There's no standing out against you, sir, I see that. Either your importunitie, or the intimation of your good parts; or—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Nay, I'le bribe his porter, and the groomes of his chamber; make his doores open to mee that way, first: and then, I'le obserue my times. Say, he should extrude mee his house to day; shall I therefore desist, or let fall my suite, to morrow? No: I'le attend him, follow him, meet him? i' the street, the high waies, run by his coach, neuer leaue him. What? Man hath nothing giuen him, in this life, without much labour.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: And impudence.
Archer of heauen, PHOEBVS, take thy bow,
And with a full drawne shaft, naile to the earth
This PYTHON; that I may yet run hence, and liue:
Or brawnie HERCVLES, doe thou come downe,
And (though thou mak'st it vp thy thirteenth labour)
Rescue me from this HYDRA of discourse, here.
HORACE, well met.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: O welcome, my releeuer,
ARISTIVS, As thou lou'st me, ransome me.

sp.speaker: ARIS.
sp.l: What ayl'st thou, man?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: 'Death, I am seaz'd on here
By a Land-Remora, I cannot stirre;
Not moue, but as he please.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Wilt thou goe, HORACE?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: 'Hart! he cleaues to me like ALCIDES shirt,
Tearing my flesh, and sinnewes; Ô, I ha' beene vext
And tortur'd with him, beyond fortie feuers.
For IOVES sake, find some meanes, to take me from him.

sp.speaker: ARIS.
sp.l: Yes, I will: but I'le goe first, and tell MECOENAS.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: Come, shall we goe?

sp.speaker: ARIS.
sp.l: The iest will make his eyes runne, yfaith.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Nay, ARISTIVS?

sp.speaker: ARIS.
sp.l: Farewell, HORACE.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: 'Death! will a' leaue me? FVSCVS ARISTIVS, doe you heare? Gods of Rome! you said, you had somewhat to say to me, in priuate.

sp.speaker: ARIS.
sp.p: I, but I see, you are now imploi'd with that gentleman: 'twere offence to trouble you. I'le take some fitter oportunitie, farewell.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Mischiefe, and torment! Ô, my soule, and heart,
How are you crampt with anguish! Death it selfe
Brings not the like convulsions. Ô, this day,
That euer I should view thy tedious face—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.l: HORACE, what passion? what humour is this?

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.l: Away, good prodigie, afflict me not.
(A friend, and mocke me thus!) neuer was man
So left vnder the axe— how now.

sp.p: THat's he, in the imbrodered hat, there, with the ash-colour'd feather: his name is LABERIVS CRISPINVS.

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: LABERIVS CRISPINVS; I arrest you in the Emperours name.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Me, sir? doe you arrest me?

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: I, sir, at the sute of Master MINOS the pothecarie.

sp.speaker: HORA.
sp.p: Thankes, great APOLLO: I will not slip thy fauour offered me in my escape, for my fortunes.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Master MINOS? I know no master MINOS. Where's HORACE? HORACE? HORACE?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Sir, doe not you know me?

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: O yes; I know you, master MINOS: 'cry you mercy. But HORACE? Gods me, is he gone?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: I, and so would you too, if you knew how. Officer, looke to him.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Doe you heare, master MINOS? pray let's be vs'd like a man of our owne fashion. By IANVS, and IVPITER, I meant to haue paied you next weeke, euery drachme. Seeke not to eclipse my reputation, thus vulgarly.

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Sir, your oathes cannot serue you, you know I haue forborne you long.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: I am conscious of it, sir. Nay, I beseech you, gentlemen, doe not exhale me thus; remember 'tis but for sweet meates—

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: Sweet meat must haue sowre sawce, sir. Come along.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Sweet, master MINOS: I am forfeited to eternall disgrace, if you doe not commiserate. Good officer, be not so officious.

div.head: Act III. Scene IIII.
div.stage: TVCCA, PYRGVS, MINOS, LICTORS, CRISPINVS, HISTRIO, DEMETRIVS.

sp.p: WHy, how now, my good brace of bloud-hounds? whither doe you dragge the gent'man? you mungrels, you curres, you bandogs, wee are Captaine TVCCA, that talke to you, you inhumane pilchers.

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Sir, he is their prisoner.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Their pestilence. What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: A citizen of Rome, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Then you are not farre distant from a foole, sir.

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: A pothecarie, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: I knew thou wast not a physician; fough: out of my nostrils, thou stink'st of lotium, and the syringe: away, quack-saluer. Follower, my sword.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: Here, noble leader, youle doe no harme with it: I'le trust you.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Doe you heare, you, good-man slaue? hooke, ramme, rogue, catch-pole, lose the gent'man, or by my veluet armes—

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: What will you doe, sir? The Officer strikes vp his heeles.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Kisse thy hand, my honourable actiue varlet: and imbrace thee, thus.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: O patient metamorphosis!

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: My sword, my tall rascall.

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: Nay, soft, sir: Some wiser then some.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: What? and a wit to! By PLVTO, thou must bee cherish'd, slaue; here's three drachmes for thee: hold.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: There's halfe his lendings gone.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Giue mee.

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: No, sir, your first word shall stand: I'le hold all.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Nay, but, rogue—

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: You would make a rescue of our prisoner, sir, you?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: I, a rescue? away inhumane varlet. Come, come, I neuer rellish aboue one iest at most; doe not disgust me: Sirra, doe not. Rogue, I tell thee, rogue, doe not.

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: How, sir? rogue?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: I, why! thou art not angrie, rascall? art thou?

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir, I am little better, vpon these termes.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Ha! gods, and fiends! why, do'st heare? rogue, thou, giue me thy hand; I say vnto thee, thy hand: rogue. What? do'st not thou know me? not me, rogue? not Captaine TVCCA, rogue?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Come: pra' surrender the gentleman his sword, officer; we'll haue no fighting here.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: What's thy name?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: MINOS, an't please you.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: MINOS? come, hither, MINOS; Thou art a wise fellow, it seemes: Let me talke with thee.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Was euer wretch so wretched, as vnfortunate I?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Thou art one of the centum-viri, old boy, art' not?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: No, indeed, master Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Goe to, thou shalt be, then: I'le ha' thee one, MINOS. Take my sword from those rascals, do'st thou see? goe, doe it: I cannot attempt with patience. What does this gentleman owe thee, little MINOS?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Fourescore sesterties, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: What? no more? Come, thou shalt release him, MINOS: what, I'le bee his baile, thou shalt take my word, old boy, and casheere these furies: thou shalt do't, I say, thou shalt, little MINOS, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: Yes, and as I am a gentleman, and a reueller, I'le make a peece of poetrie, and absolue all, within these fiue daies.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Come, MINOS is not to learne how to vse a gent'man of qualitie, I know; My sword: If hee pay thee not, I will, and I must, old boy. Thou shalt bee my pothecary too: ha'st good eringo's, MINOS?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: The best in Rome, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Goe too then— Vermine, know the house.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: I warrant you, Collonell.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: For this gentleman, MINOS?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: I'le take your word, Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Thou hast it, my sword—

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Yes, sir: but you must discharge the arrest, Master CRISPINVS.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: How, MINOS? looke in the gentlemans face, and but reade his silence. Pay, pay; 'tis honour, MINOS.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: By IOVE, sweet Captaine, you doe most infinitely endeare, and oblige me to you.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Tut, I cannot complement, by MARS: but IVPITER loue me, as I loue good wordes, and good clothes, and there's an end. Thou shalt giue my boy that girdle, and hangers, when thou hast worne them a little more—

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: O IVPITER! Captaine, he shall haue them now, presently: please you to be acceptiue, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: Yes, sir, feare not; I shall accept: I haue a prettie foolish humour of taking, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Not now, you shall not take, boy.

sp.speaker: CRIS.
sp.p: By my truth, and earnest, but hee shall, Captaine, by your leaue.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Nay, and a' sweare by his truth, and earnest, take it boy: doe not make a gent'man forsworne.

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: Well, sir, there is your sword; but thanke master MINOS: you had not carried it as you doe, else.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: MINOS is iust, and you are knaues, and—

sp.speaker: LICT.
sp.p: What say you, sir?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Passe on, my good scoundrell, passe on, I honour thee: But, that I hate to haue action with such base rogues as these; you should ha' seene me vnrip their noses now, and haue sent 'hem to the next barbers, to stitching: for, doe you see— I am a man of humour, and I doe loue the varlets, the honest varlets; they haue wit, and valour: and are indeed good profitable— errant rogues, as any liue in an empire. Doest thou heare, POETASTER? second me. Stand vp (MINOS) close, gather, yet, so. Sir (thou shalt haue a quarter share, bee resolute) you shall, at my request, take MINOS by the hand, here, little MINOS, I will haue it so; all friends, and a health: Be not inexorable. And thou shalt impart the wine, old boy, thou shalt do't, little MINOS, thou shalt: make vs pay it in our physicke. What? we must liue, and honour the gods, sometimes; now BACCHVS, now COMVS, now PRIAPVS: euery god, a little. What's he, that stalkes by, there? boy, PYRGVS, you were best let him passe, sirrah; doe, ferret, let him passe, doe.

sp.speaker: PYRG.
sp.p: 'Tis a player, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p:
A player? Call him, call the lowsie slaue hither: what, will he saile by, and not once strike, or vaile to a Man of warre? ha? doe you
heare? you, player, rogue, stalker, come backe here: no respect to men of worship, you slaue? What, you are proud, you rascall, are you proud? ha? you grow rich, doe you? and purchase, you two-penny teare-mouth? you haue fortune, and the good yeere on your side, you stinkard? you haue? you haue?

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: Nay, sweet Captaine, be confin'd to some reason; I protest I saw you not, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: You did not? where was your sight, OEDIPVS? you walke with hares eies, doe you? I'le ha' 'hem glas'd, rogue; and you say the word, they shall be glaz'd for you: come, we must haue you turne fiddler againe, slaue, get a base violin at your backe, and march in a tawnie coate, with one sleeue, to Goose-faire, and then you'll know vs; you'll see vs then; you will, gulch, you will? Then, wil't please your worship to haue any musicke, Captaine?

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: Nay, good Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: What? doe you laugh, Owleglas? death, you persemptuous varlet, I am none of your fellowes: I haue commanded a hundred and fiftie such rogues, I.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.p: I, and most of that hundred and fiftie, haue beene leaders of a legion.

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: If I haue exhibited wrong, I'le tender satisfaction, Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Sai'st thou so, honest vermine? Giue me thy hand, thou shalt make vs a supper one of these nights.

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: When you please, by IOVE, Captaine, most willingly.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Doest thou sweare? to morrow then; say, and hold slaue. There are some of you plaiers honest gent'man-like scoundrels, and suspected to ha' some wit, as well as your poets; both at drinking, and breaking of iests: and are companions for gallants. A man may skelder yee, now and then, of halfe a dozen shillings, or so. Doest thou not know that PANTALABVS there?

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: No, I assure you, Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Goe, and bee acquainted with him, then; hee is a gent'man, parcell-poet, you slaue: his father was a man of worship, I tell thee. Goe, he pens high, loftie, in a new stalking straine; bigger then halfe the rimers i' the towne, againe: he was borne to fill thy mouth, MINOTAVRVS, he was: hee will teach thee to teare, and rand, Rascall, to him, cherish his muse, goe: thou hast fortie, fortie, shillings, I meane, stinkard, giue him in earnest, doe, he shall write for thee, slaue. If hee pen for thee once, thou shalt not need to trauell, with thy pumps full of grauell, any more, after a blinde iade and a hamper: and stalke vpon boords, and barrell heads, to an old crackt trumpet—

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: Troth, I thinke I ha' not so much about me, Captaine.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p:
It's no matter: giue him what thou hast: Stiffe toe, I'le giue my word for the rest: though it lacke a shilling, or two, it skils not: Goe, thou art an honest shifter, I'le ha' the statute repeal'd for thee. MINOS,
must tell thee, MINOS, thou hast deiected you gent'mans spirit exceedingly: do'st obserue? do'st note, little MINOS?

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Goe to then, raise; recouer, doe. Suffer him not to droop, in prospect of a player, a rogue, a stager: put twentie into his hand, twentie, sesterces, I meane, and let no bodie see: goe, doe it, the worke shall commend it selfe, be MINOS, I'le pay.

sp.speaker: MINO.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, Captaine.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.p: Doe not we serue a notable sharke?

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: And what new matters haue you now afoot, sirrah? ha? I would faine come with my cockatrice one day, and see a play; if I knew when there were a good bawdie one: but they say, you ha' nothing but humours, reuells, and satyres, that girde, and fart at the time, you slaue.

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: No, I assure you, Captaine, not wee. They are on the other side of Tyber: we haue as much ribaldrie in our plaies, as can bee, as you would wish, Captaine: All the sinners, i' the suburbs, come, and applaud our action, daily.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: I heare, you'll bring me o' the stage there; you'll play me, they say: I shall be presented by a sort of copper-lac't scoundrels of you: life of PLVTO, and you stage me, stinkard; your mansions shall sweat for't, your tabernacles, varlets, your Globes, and your Triumphs.

sp.speaker: HIST.
sp.p: Not we, by PHOEBVS, Captaine: doe not doe vs imputation without desert.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: I wu' not, my good two-penny rascall: reach mee thy neufe. Do'st heare? What wilt thou giue mee a weeke, for my brace of beagles, here, my little point-trussers? you shall ha' them act among yee. Sirrah, you, pronounce. Thou shalt heare him speake, in king DARIVS dolefull straine.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: O dolefull dayes! O direfull deadly dump!
O wicked world! and worldly wickednesse!
How can I hold my fist from crying, thump,
In rue of this right rascall wretchednesse!

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.l: In an amorous vaine now, sirrah, peace.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: O, shee is wilder, and more hard, withall,
Then beast, or bird, or tree, or stonie wall.
Yet might shee loue me, to vpreare her state:
I, but perhaps, shee hopes some nobler mate.
Yet might shee loue me, to content her sire:
I, but her reason masters her desire.
Yet might shee loue me as her beauties thrall:
I, but I feare, shee cannot loue at all.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.l: Now, the horrible fierce Souldier, you, sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: What? will I braue thee? I, and beard thee too.
A roman spirit scornes to beare a braine,
So full of base pusillanimitie.

sp.speaker: DEMET. HIST.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.l: Nay, thou shalt see that, shall rauish thee anon: prick vp thine eares, stinkard: the Ghost, boies.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.l: Timoria.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: Vindicta.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.l: Timoria.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: Veni.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.l: Veni.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.l: Now, thunder, sirrah, you, the rumbling plaier.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: I, but some bodie must crie (murder) then, in a small voice.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.l: Your fellow-sharer, there, shall do't; Crie, sirrah, crie.

sp.speaker: 1. PYR.
sp.l: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.l: Who calls out murder? lady, was it you?

sp.speaker: DEMET. HIST.
sp.l: O, admirable good, I protest.

sp.speaker: TVCC.
sp.p: Sirrah, boy, brace your drumme a little straighter, and doe the t'other fellow there, hee in the— what sha' call him— and yet, stay too.

sp.speaker: 2. PYR.
sp.l: Nay, and thou dalliest, then I am thy foe,
And feare shall force, what friendship cannot win;
Thy death shall burie what thy life conceales,
